argues that it is for this reason that unconstrained communication is imperative to social progress, since analysis and critique of the bourgeois society is one way to "unmask" these ideologies and cause the bourgeois to confront the contradiction between the idea and reality of its society.<ref name="Harris">{{cite web|last1=Harris|first1=Dave|title=Reading Guide to Habermas, J (1976) Legitimation Crisis, London: Heinemann Educational Books (Trans. and intro. by Thomas McCarthy)|url=http://www.arasite.org/hablc.htm|website=Dave Harris & Colleagues}}</ref> Crises in liberal capitalism arise through unresolved economic steering problems.<ref name="Habermas24">{{cite book|last1=Habermas|first1=Jürgen|title=Legitimation Crisis|date=1975|publisher=Beacon Press|location=Boston|page=24}}</ref> As a result, markets steer the social formation not only through the use of money and power but through ideology, although they appear to be anonymous and unpolitical entities.<ref name="Harris">{{cite web|last1=Harris|first1=Dave|title=Reading Guide to Habermas, J (1976) Legitimation Crisis, London: Heinemann Educational Books (Trans. and intro. by Thomas McCarthy)|url=http://www.arasite.org/hablc.htm|website=Dave Harris & Colleagues}}</ref> * ''[[Advanced capitalism]]'' has its principle of organization in the process of economic concentration.<ref name="Chung">{{cite book|last1=Chung|first1=Paul S.|title=Church and Ethical Responsibility in the Midst of World Economy: Greed, Dominion, and Justice|date=2013|publisher=Cascade Books|page=165}}</ref> This social formation exists when the capitalist model becomes deeply integrated in a society and continues to develop extensively for a prolonged period of time. The crisis tendencies of advanced capitalism stem from the three subsystems: economic crises from the economic system; rationality and legitimation crises from the political system; and motivation crises from the socio-cultural system.<ref name="Harris">{{cite web|last1=Harris|first1=Dave|title=Reading Guide to Habermas, J (1976) Legitimation Crisis, London: Heinemann Educational Books (Trans. and intro. by Thomas McCarthy)|url=http://www.arasite.org/hablc.htm|website=Dave Harris & Colleagues}}</ref><ref name="Chung">{{cite book|last1=Chung|first1=Paul S.|title=Church and Ethical Responsibility in the Midst of World Economy: Greed, Dominion, and Justice|date=2013|publisher=Cascade Books|page=165}}</ref>
===Legitimation crisis tendencies===
The political subsystem of the social world requires an input of mass loyalty in order to produce an output, which consists of legitimate administrative decisions that are executed by the state.<ref name="Habermas46">{{cite book|last1=Habermas|first1=Jürgen|title=Legitimation Crisis|date=1975|publisher=Beacon Press|location=Boston|page=46}}</ref> A ''rationality crisis'' is an output crisis that occurs when the state fails to meet the demands of the economy.<ref name="Scambler">{{cite web|last1=Scambler|first1=Graham|title=Habermas and Crisis Tendencies|url=http://www.grahamscambler.com/habermas-and-crises-tendencies/|website=Graham Scambler Discover Society Blog}}</ref><ref name="Habermas46-48">{{cite book|last1=Habermas|first1=Jürgen|title=Legitimation Crisis|date=1975|publisher=Beacon Press|location=Boston|pages=46–48}}</ref> A ''legitimation crisis'', on the other hand, is an input crisis that occurs when "the legitimation system does not succeed in maintaining the requisite level of mass loyalty."<ref name="Habermas46">{{cite book|last1=Habermas|first1=Jürgen|title=Legitimation Crisis|date=1975|publisher=Beacon Press|location=Boston|page=46}}</ref> It is an identity crisis in which administrations are unable to establish normative structures to the extent required for the entire system to function properly.<ref name="Habermas47">{{cite book|last1=Habermas|first1=Jürgen|title=Legitimation Crisis|date=1975|publisher=Beacon Press|location=Boston|page=47}}</ref> As a result, the state suffers a loss of support by the public when the electorate judges its administration unaccountable.<ref name="Scambler">{{cite web|last1=Scambler|first1=Graham|title=Habermas and Crisis Tendencies|url=http://www.grahamscambler.com/habermas-and-crises-tendencies/|website=Graham Scambler Discover Society Blog}}</ref><ref name="Peter">{{cite journal|last1=Hohendah|first1=Peter Uwe|title=Critical Theory, Public Sphere and Culture. Jiurgen Habermas and his Critics|journal=New German Critique|date=1979|volume=16|page=112|jstor=487878|doi=10.2307/487878}}</ref> This loss of public confidence is one of many characteristics of a legitimation crisis, among them issues such as policy incoherence and loss of institutional will.<ref name="Held">{{cite book|last1=Held|first1=David|title=Models of Democracy|date=2006|publisher=Stanford University Press|location=Cambridge|page=195|edition=3rd}}</ref>
==Historical examples== In the past, there have been many examples of social upheaval and systemic power exchanges that can be classified as legitimation crises. According to Habermas, these crises have all occurred as a natural consequence of society's productive advancement, as the social system struggles to adapt to the strains on relations of production. In other words, as a society's "technical knowledge" advances, the equilibrium is disturbed between the technical and political aspects of production, which can result in a crisis if the imbalance isn't corrected by adequate advancement of "moral-practical knowledge." <ref name="Owen">{{cite book|last1=Owen|first1=David|title=Between Reason and History: Habermas and the Idea of Progress|date=2002|publisher=State University of New York Press|location=Albany|pages=59–60}}</ref> A prime example of this is in the process of [[industrialization]], where the establishment of factories and massive workforces often precedes the establishment of government regulations, workers' rights and labor unions. As sociologist [[Robert K. Merton|Robert Merton]] explains, a group is most successful and stable when it is satisfied by the achievement of its institutional goals (technical/forces of production) and also with the institutional norms and regulations condoned to achieve those goals (moral-practical/relations of production). Therefore, in order to maintain legitimacy, a society, constituted by both the government and the governed, must engage in an ongoing and competitive reevaluation of its goals and norms to ensure they continue to satisfy the society's needs. The establishment of new social movements is essential to this process.
Historically, the most stable societies have been those that enjoy widespread acceptance of both the society's institutional goals and the means used to achieve them. In contrast, every crisis of legitimacy has occurred when a large and/or important portion of a society strongly disagrees with some or all aspects of the institutional norms, as established and advanced by a particular regime or government.<ref name="Merton">{{cite journal|last1=Merton|first1=Robert|title=Social Structure and Anomie|journal=American Sociological Review|date=1938|volume=3|pages=672–682|doi=10.2307/2084686}}</ref> When a government loses support, in this regard, it risks losing its legitimacy, as the public begins to question and doubt the grounds upon which the government's claim to power is built.<ref name="Zhong201-221">{{cite journal|last1=Zhong|first1=Yang|title=Legitimacy Crisis and Legitimation in China|journal=Journal of Contemporary Asia|date=1996|volume=26|pages=201–221|doi=10.1080/00472339680000131}}</ref> In dealing with these crises, individuals and groups of individuals in the society resort to various modes of adjustment or adaptation.<ref name="Merton">{{cite journal|last1=Merton|first1=Robert|title=Social Structure and Anomie|journal=American Sociological Review|date=1938|volume=3|pages=672–682|doi=10.2307/2084686}}</ref> Historically, these have usually cropped up in the form of revolutions, coups and wars.
Additionally, it is important to note that the logic of legitimation strongly depends on the system of domination deployed. In fact, it's the logic of legitimation that informs the concrete ways citizens and subjects comply to authority and/or contend with authority. In other words, the basis for any claim to legitimacy is often the basis for resistance against that same claim to legitimacy. For example, in some societies the economic achievements under a particular regime or government form the basis for its legitimation claims; in those societies, counterclaims to legitimacy will often highlight economic failures in order to strategically undermine the regime or government's authority.<ref name="Shue">{{cite book|last1=Shue|first1=Vivienne|title=State and Society in 21st-Century China|date=2004|publisher=RoutledgeCurzon|location=New York|pages=27–28|chapter=Legitimacy crisis in China?}}</ref> Max Weber, who first advanced this point, summarizes it below:
::every...system [of domination] attempts to establish and to cultivate the belief in its legitimacy. But according to the kind of legitimacy which is claimed, the type of obedience, the kind of administrative staff developed to guarantee it, and the mode of exercising authority, will all differ fundamentally.<ref name="Weber">{{cite book|last1=Weber|first1=Max|title=Economy and Society: An Outline of Interpretive Sociology|date=1978|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley|page=213}}</ref>
===Revolutionary France=== The events of the [[French Revolution]], from 1789 to 1799, and the socio-political changes that it comprised can be classified as a legitimation crisis. The revolution was characteristic of a time in Europe where the divine right of monarchical rule was being undermined and transformed as the universal rights of the common citizen were emphasized instead.<ref name="How187">{{cite journal|last1=How|first1=Alan|title=Habermas, History and Social Evolution: Moral Learning and the Trial of Louis XVI|journal=Sociology|date=February 2001|volume=35|pages=187|doi=10.1177/0038038501035001011}}</ref> Consequently, the mythological world views that underpinned the governing institutions of law and that bound popular conceptions of morality were replaced with more rational ones.<ref name="How186">{{cite journal|last1=How|first1=Alan|title=Habermas, History and Social Evolution: Moral Learning and the Trial of Louis XVI|journal=Sociology|date=February 2001|volume=35|pages=186|doi=10.1177/0038038501035001011}}</ref>
===People's Republic of China===
The legitimation crisis in China took place after decades of power struggles and cultural shifts that had been in effect since the 1960s. The legitimation crisis, itself, was the result of several economic and political reforms made by the [[Communist Party of China]] (CPC) as part of an effort to salvage their reputation after the [[socialism|socialist]] policies and [[populism|populist]] leadership of [[Mao Zedong]] in the 60s and 70s had left the Chinese economy in poor condition.
During Mao's rule, an informal [[social contract]] was established, in which the government would supply socialist benefits (e.g. egalitarianism, food and shelter, medical care, education, job security, stable prices, social stability, and elimination of social evils) in return for the public's acquiescence to one-party rule and the loss of some civil liberties and political rights.<ref name="History">{{cite web|last1=History.com Staff|title=Cultural Revolution|url=http://history.com/topics/cultural-revolution|publisher=A+E Networks|website=history.com|accessdate=10 November 2014}}</ref> However, in the midst of the a time referred to as the [[Cultural Revolution]] from 1966 to 1976, the social contract was put in jeopardy as political and social stability faded.<ref name="Zhong5-6">{{cite journal|last1=Zhong|first1=Yang|title=Legitimacy Crisis and Legitimation in China|journal=Journal of Contemporary Asia|date=1996|volume=26|pages=5–6}}</ref> When Mao died in 1976, a brief crisis of legitimation followed, as the cult of personality died with him and the CPC was left without its last strong grounds for authority. Since the party's core socialist policies had also failed, in order to regain and maintain legitimacy the party was forced to shift away from its longstanding focus on Marxist ideology, economic socialism, and charismatic appeals to focusing on political and economic rationalization and legalization instead.<ref name="Zhong7">{{cite journal|last1=Zhong|first1=Yang|title=Legitimacy Crisis and Legitimation in China|journal=Journal of Contemporary Asia|date=1996|volume=26|pages=7|doi=10.1080/00472339680000131}}</ref> The party's economic achievements (e.g. improved standard of living, growth and development) under its newly liberalized policies became the primary evidence of its legitimacy. In essence, the reforms were a solid move away from a control-oriented economy towards a more market-oriented, capitalist one.<ref name="Dickson">{{cite book|last1=Dickson|first1=Bruce J.|editor1-last=Gries|editor1-first=Peter Hays|editor2-last=Rosen|editor2-first=Stanley|publisher=RoutledgeCurzon|location=New York City|pages=141|title=Dilemmas of Party adaptation: The CCP's strategies for survival}}</ref>
The CPC faced a new legitimation crisis with the move toward capitalism, as it violated the terms of the previously established social contract (inflation rose, the income gap widened, job insecurity increased, social welfare programs deteriorated and social evils returned) and the CPC's claim to one-party rule was challenged, as the public began to wonder why they were necessary as a party if socialism had failed and capitalism was the answer;<ref name="Zhong9">{{cite journal|last1=Zhong|first1=Yang|title=Legitimacy Crisis and Legitimation in China|journal=Journal of Contemporary Asia|date=1996|volume=26|pages=9|doi=10.1080/00472339680000131}}</ref> after all, the CPC's leaders were not the most qualified to exercise market-oriented economic reforms. The shift towards capitalist policies coupled with the CPC's inability to accommodate increased pressure for political liberalization and democratization eventually culminated in the Chinese democracy movement and the Tiananmen Square protests of 1989.<ref name="Zhong1">{{cite journal|last1=Zhong|first1=Yang|title=Legitimacy Crisis and Legitimation in China|journal=Journal of Contemporary Asia|date=1996|volume=26|pages=1|doi=10.1080/00472339680000131}}</ref>
===Postcolonial Africa=== In the twentieth-century, as African states adjusted to postcolonial independence, legitimation crises and state collapse were constant threats.<ref name="Zartman1">{{cite book|last1=Zartman|first1=I. William|title=Collapsed States: The Disintegration and Restoration of Legitimate Authority|date=1995|publisher=Lynne Reinner Publishers, Inc.|location=Colorado|pages=1}}</ref> While authority was passed from colonial to independent rule successfully in most African states throughout the continent, some attempts at transition resulted in collapse. In Congo, for example, the state collapsed as its respective institutions (e.g. army, executives, local governments, populations) refused to recognize each other's authority and work together.<ref name="Zartman2">{{cite book|last1=Zartman|first1=I. William|title=Collapsed States: The Disintegration and Restoration of Legitimate Authority|date=1995|publisher=Lynne Reinner Publishers, Inc.|location=Colorado|pages=2}}</ref> It took international intervention and the installation of a strongman with foreign connivance to reconstitute the state there.
[[File:JStalin Secretary general CCCP 1942.jpg|thumb|left|[[Joseph Stalin]]'s brand of communism successfully took hold due to a combination of terror and charisma.]]
In other African countries, state collapse was not a strictly postcolonial issue, as most states had some success transferring between regimes. Problems arose, however, when second-generation (and later) regimes began overthrowing original nationalist ones. Chad, Uganda, and Ghana are all instances of this happening – in each, a successfully established, but dysfunctional independent regime was replaced by a military regime that managed to concentrate power, but failed to effectively wield it. Legitimation crises and state collapse soon followed.<ref name="Zartman3">{{cite book|last1=Zartman|first1=I. William|title=Collapsed States: The Disintegration and Restoration of Legitimate Authority|date=1995|publisher=Lynne Reinner Publishers, Inc.|location=Colorado|pages=3}}</ref>
===Eastern Europe=== In Eastern European countries where [[Stalinism]] was the system of domination, the legitimacy of the system was dependent on the instillment of fear among citizens and the charisma of the state leader.<ref name="Heller141">{{cite book|last1=Heller|first1=Agnes|editor1-last=Tismaneanu|editor1-first=Vladimir|title=Legitimation Deficit and Legitimation Crisis in East European Socieites|date=2009|publisher=Central European University Press|location=Budapest|page=141}}</ref><ref name="Lewis">{{cite book|last1=Lewis|first1=Paul G.|title=Eastern Europe: Political Crisis and Legitimation|date=1984|publisher=Croom Held Australia Pty Ltd|location=Australia|pages=3}}</ref> This was the strategy that worked for [[Joseph Stalin|Stalin]], himself, in the Soviet Union, as his brand of terror and charisma inspired a strong personality cult that placed authority and legitimacy in Stalin's hands alone.<ref name="Heller142">{{cite book|last1=Heller|first1=Agnes|editor1-last=Tismaneanu|editor1-first=Vladimir|title=Legitimation Deficit and Legitimation Crisis in East European Socieites|date=2009|publisher=Central European University Press|location=Budapest|page=142}}</ref> For other Eastern European states, however, Soviet [[communism]] was a foreign system that had to be imported. This proved to be a major problem, as the communist leaders in other Eastern European states lacked Stalin's charisma.
Furthermore, communism was implemented in other East European states (e.g. Romania, Hungary, Poland) in a much shorter time frame and developed very differently from the way it did in the Soviet Union.<ref name="Heller143">{{cite book|last1=Heller|first1=Agnes|editor1-last=Tismaneanu|editor1-first=Vladimir|title=Legitimation Deficit and Legitimation Crisis in East European Socieites|date=2009|publisher=Central European University Press|location=Budapest|page=143}}</ref> In Hungary, for example, the communist party initially came to power via tacit consent to a coalition government. Over time, the party began to strategically gain more power and get rid of competition. However, the democratic means the communist parties in these states initially used to gain power lost credibility once they were seen as violent tyrannies in service of an alien power.<ref name="Heller154">{{cite book|last1=Heller|first1=Agnes|editor1-last=Tismaneanu|editor1-first=Vladimir|title=Legitimation Deficit and Legitimation Crisis in East European Socieites|date=2009|publisher=Central European University Press|location=Budapest|page=154}}</ref> Ultimately, populist platforms - giving farmers land, social and economic stability, and welfare benefits - gave way to brutal collectivist realities, as leaders were blamed for the very same reforms they were once praised for.<ref name="Heller155">{{cite book|last1=Heller|first1=Agnes|editor1-last=Tismaneanu|editor1-first=Vladimir|title=Legitimation Deficit and Legitimation Crisis in East European Socieites|date=2009|publisher=Central European University Press|location=Budapest|page=155}}</ref>
==Contemporary examples==
===Tunisia===
[[File:Zine El Abidine Ben Ali 2.jpg|thumb|Ben Ali, former president of Tunisia, was deposed by the Tunisian people when the Arab Spring began in his state in late 2010.]]
The [[Tunisian Revolution]] began with the self-immolation of [[Mohamed Bouazizi]] on December 17, 2010, although it is also possible to consider the miner strike in the west central town of Gafsa in 2008 to be the official beginning of the movement.<ref name="Promises132">{{cite journal|title=Promises and Challenges: The Tunisian Revolution of 2010-2011|journal=National Lawyers Guild Review|date=Fall 2011|volume=68|issue=3|page=132}}</ref> The Tunisian people toppled [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali|Ben Ali]], who had imposed a [[police state]].<ref name="Promises131-132">{{cite journal|title=Promises and Challenges: The Tunisian Revolution of 2010-2011|journal=National Lawyers Guild Review|date=Fall 2011|volume=68|issue=3|page=|pages=131–132}}</ref> The revolution, like other [[Arab Spring]] revolutions which would soon follow, was prompted by endemic poverty, rising food prices, and chronic unemployment.<ref name="Promises131">{{cite journal|title=Promises and Challenges: The Tunisian Revolution of 2010-2011|journal=National Lawyers Guild Review|date=Fall 2011|volume=68|issue=3|page=131}}</ref> Tunisians demanded democracy, human rights, the end of corruption, and the end of the enforcement of the [[Terrorism Acts|2003 Anti-Terrorism Act]], which effectively criminalized their religious ideas and practices.<ref name="Promises132"/><ref name="Tunsian">{{cite news|title=Tunisian anti-terrorism law: A balance between security and freedoms|url=https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/news/africa/12016-tunisian-anti-terrorism-law-a-balance-between-security-and-freedoms|accessdate=25 November 2014|publisher=Middle East Monitor|date=June 10, 2014}}</ref>
The previous legitimacy of the Tunisian government had been based on a combination of the charisma of former president [[Habib Bourguiba|Bourguiba's]] secular legacy and an achievement legitimacy based on the modernization of the Tunisian state.<ref name="Redissi383">{{cite journal|last1=Redissi|first1=Hamadi|title=The decline of political Islam's legitimacy: The Tunisian case|journal=Philosophy and Social Criticism|date=May 2014|volume=40|issue=4/5|page=383|doi=10.1177/0191453714527286}}</ref> After this legitimacy had failed and its accompanying regime had fallen, [[Ennahda Movement|En-Nahdha]], an Islamist party, sought to provide legitimacy through criticism of the previous regime.<ref name="Redissi382">{{cite journal|last1=Redissi|first1=Hamadi|title=The decline of political Islam's legitimacy: The Tunisian case|journal=Philosophy and Social Criticism|date=May 2014|volume=40|issue=4/5|page=382|doi=10.1177/0191453714527286}}</ref> Tunisia initiated a top-down modernization, led by civil, urban, and secular petty bourgeoisie,<ref name="Redissi383"/> contrasting with the military coups in Egypt, Syria, and Iraq, the leadership of traditional scriptural elites in Morocco and Libya, and the leadership of revolutionary armed peasantry in Algeria.<ref name="Redissi383"/>
Tunisians asked that a [[Constituent Assembly of Tunisia|National Constituent Assembly]] (NCA) be formed that would be charged with writing the new constitution.<ref name="Redissi384">{{cite journal|last1=Redissi|first1=Hamadi|title=The decline of political Islam's legitimacy: The Tunisian case|journal=Philosophy and Social Criticism|date=May 2014|volume=40|issue=4/5|page=384|doi=10.1177/0191453714527286}}</ref> The party of the former regime, the [[Democratic Constitutional Rally|Constitutional Democratic Rally]] (RCD) was banned from running for re-election, and En-Nahdha received 40% of the vote in an election overseen by a higher independent authority in April 2011.<ref name="Redissi384"/> With its share of 89 out of 217 total seats, En-Nahdha then formed a coalition in the form of a [[triumvirate]], or troika, with the [[Congress for the Republic]] and the Forum known as [[Democratic Forum for Labour and Liberties|Ettakatul]] within the NCA.<ref name="Redissi385">{{cite journal|last1=Redissi|first1=Hamadi|title=The decline of political Islam's legitimacy: The Tunisian case|journal=Philosophy and Social Criticism|date=May 2014|volume=40|issue=4/5|page=385|doi=10.1177/0191453714527286}}</ref>
En-Nahdha then seized considerable control by appointing 83% of public agents at all levels, and shutting down the media by physically attacking hundreds of journalists.<ref name="Redissi385"/> En-Nahdha was also suspected of several assassinations, prompting the resignation of En-Nahdha prime minister [[Hamadi Jebali]] in April 2013.<ref name="Redissi385"/> En-Nahdha also failed to produce a constitution by the agreed-upon time of a year, causing many political parties, including the major political party [[Nidaa Tounes]], to declare the end of En-Nahdha's electoral legitimacy.<ref name="Redissi386">{{cite journal|last1=Redissi|first1=Hamadi|title=The decline of political Islam's legitimacy: The Tunisian case|journal=Philosophy and Social Criticism|date=May 2014|volume=40|issue=4/5|page=386|doi=10.1177/0191453714527286}}</ref>
The Tunisian public and political parties then asked for a compromise legitimacy that consisted of a mandatory national dialogue between En-Nahdha and the other ruling members of the NCA, which began in October 2013.<ref name="Redissi386"/> This effectively forced En-Nahdha to negotiate its own immediate departure from the government, while at the same time conceding the current failure of Islamism as a means of legitimacy. The national dialogue, which is still taking place, is seeking to establish a legitimate government, end the legislative process for the constitution and electoral code, and set up an independent body to organize elections and fix a definitive date.<ref name="Redissi388">{{cite journal|last1=Redissi|first1=Hamadi|title=The decline of political Islam's legitimacy: The Tunisian case|journal=Philosophy and Social Criticism|date=May 2014|volume=40|issue=4/5|page=388|doi=10.1177/0191453714527286}}</ref>
===Libya===
[[File:Muammar al-Gaddafi at the AU summit-LR.jpg|thumb|left|Muammar Gaddafi, former leader of Libya, held power for four decades and fought violently against protestors during the 2011 Arab Spring uprising in Libya.]]
Libya's revolution is also considered part of the Arab Spring, beginning February 15, 2011,<ref name="Ghosh">{{cite journal|last1=Ghosh|first1=Bobby|last2=Walt|first2=Vivienne|last3=Hauslohner|first3=Abigail|last4=Harrell|first4=Eben|last5=Perry|first5=Alex|last6=Scherer|first6=Michael|last7=Calabresi|first7=Massimo|title=Gaddafi's Last Stand|journal=Time|date=March 7, 2011|volume=177|issue=9}}</ref> just a few months after the events in Tunisia. The revolution deposed [[Muammar Gaddafi]],<ref name="Ghosh">{{cite journal|last1=Ghosh|first1=Bobby|last2=Walt|first2=Vivienne|last3=Hauslohner|first3=Abigail|last4=Harrell|first4=Eben|last5=Perry|first5=Alex|last6=Scherer|first6=Michael|last7=Calabresi|first7=Massimo|title=Gaddafi's Last Stand|journal=Time|date=March 7, 2011|volume=177|issue=9}}</ref> who had been the ruler of Libya for four decades<ref name="Chertoff">{{cite journal|last1=Chertoff|first1=Meryl|last2=Green|first2=Michael|title=Revitalizing the Rule of Law|journal=Harvard International Review|date=Fall 2012|volume=34|issue=2|page=61}}</ref> and had united the country under the themes of [[Pan-Arabism]] (a form of nationalism), common geography, shared history, and Islam.<ref name="Libya">{{cite journal|title=Libya can now reimagine itself|journal=Christian Science Monitor|date=August 22, 2011}}</ref> The revolution was an attempt to replace these forms of legitimacy with democratic legitimacy<ref name="Libya">{{cite journal|title=Libya can now reimagine itself|journal=Christian Science Monitor|date=August 22, 2011}}</ref> via the [[National Transitional Council]].<ref name="Chertoff">{{cite journal|last1=Chertoff|first1=Meryl|last2=Green|first2=Michael|title=Revitalizing the Rule of Law|journal=Harvard International Review|date=Fall 2012|volume=34|issue=2|page=61}}</ref><ref name="Libya">{{cite journal|title=Libya can now reimagine itself|journal=Christian Science Monitor|date=August 22, 2011}}</ref>
Gaddafi's legitimacy waned as his regime failed to benefit those of most need in the state. Although Libya has the world's ninth-largest known oil deposits and a population of only 6.5 million,<ref name="Ghosh">{{cite journal|last1=Ghosh|first1=Bobby|last2=Walt|first2=Vivienne|last3=Hauslohner|first3=Abigail|last4=Harrell|first4=Eben|last5=Perry|first5=Alex|last6=Scherer|first6=Michael|last7=Calabresi|first7=Massimo|title=Gaddafi's Last Stand|journal=Time|date=March 7, 2011|volume=177|issue=9}}</ref> in 2010, Gallup polls showed that 29% of young Libyans were unemployed, and 93% of young Libyans described their condition as “struggling” or “suffering.”<ref name="Ghosh">{{cite journal|last1=Ghosh|first1=Bobby|last2=Walt|first2=Vivienne|last3=Hauslohner|first3=Abigail|last4=Harrell|first4=Eben|last5=Perry|first5=Alex|last6=Scherer|first6=Michael|last7=Calabresi|first7=Massimo|title=Gaddafi's Last Stand|journal=Time|date=March 7, 2011|volume=177|issue=9}}</ref> As protestors took to the streets, Gaddafi dispatched tanks, jets,<ref name="Ghosh">{{cite journal|last1=Ghosh|first1=Bobby|last2=Walt|first2=Vivienne|last3=Hauslohner|first3=Abigail|last4=Harrell|first4=Eben|last5=Perry|first5=Alex|last6=Scherer|first6=Michael|last7=Calabresi|first7=Massimo|title=Gaddafi's Last Stand|journal=Time|date=March 7, 2011|volume=177|issue=9}}</ref> and mercenaries<ref name="Eldin192">{{cite journal|last1=Eldin|first1=Kamal|last2=Salih|first2=Osman|title=The Roots and Causes of the 2011 Arab Uprisings|journal=Arab Studies Quarterly|date=Spring 2013|volume=35|issue=2|page=192}}</ref> to attack them, inciting a string of defections and so further eroding his legitimacy as a ruler. The actual death count of these attacks is not known, as Gaddafi's regime shut out and shut down both world and local media and communications.<ref name="Ghosh">{{cite journal|last1=Ghosh|first1=Bobby|last2=Walt|first2=Vivienne|last3=Hauslohner|first3=Abigail|last4=Harrell|first4=Eben|last5=Perry|first5=Alex|last6=Scherer|first6=Michael|last7=Calabresi|first7=Massimo|title=Gaddafi's Last Stand|journal=Time|date=March 7, 2011|volume=177|issue=9}}</ref> However, Libya's militarily weak regime<ref name="Joshi">{{cite journal|last1=Joshi|first1=Shashank|title=Six Lessons from Libya|journal=Military Technology|date=July 1, 2012|issue=7|page=13}}</ref> was eventually overcome, and Gaddafi was killed on October 20, 2011,<ref name="Taylor">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Adam|title=Gaddafi died 3 years ago. Would Libya be better off if he hadn’t?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2014/10/20/gaddafi-died-3-years-ago-would-libya-be-better-off-if-he-hadnt/|accessdate=25 November 2014|publisher=The Washington Post|date=October 20, 2014}}</ref> leading to the disintegration of the regime.<ref name="Eldin191-192">{{cite journal|last1=Eldin|first1=Kamal|last2=Salih|first2=Osman|title=The Roots and Causes of the 2011 Arab Uprisings|journal=Arab Studies Quarterly|date=Spring 2013|volume=35|issue=2|pages=191–192|doi=10.13169/arabstudquar.35.2.0184}}</ref>
Since Gaddafi's departure, tribal elders, [[non-governmental organization|NGOs]], youth groups, town councils, and local brigades have stepped in to fill the power vacuum.<ref name="Wehrey116">{{cite journal|last1=[[Frederic Wehrey|Wehrey]]|first1=Frederic|title=Libya's Revolution at Two Years: Perils and Achievements|journal=Mediterranean Politics|date=March 2013|volume=18|issue=1|page=116|doi=10.1080/13629395.2013.764655}}</ref> There are many different tribes in Libya, not all of which have supported the regime change,<ref name="Eldin193">{{cite journal|last1=Eldin|first1=Kamal|last2=Salih|first2=Osman|title=The Roots and Causes of the 2011 Arab Uprisings|journal=Arab Studies Quarterly|date=Spring 2013|volume=35|issue=2|page=193}}</ref> making the establishment of a new form of legitimacy difficult. However, unlike Egypt, Libya has no entrenched officer class or judiciary to prolong or obstruct the country's transition to democracy.<ref name="Wehrey116"/> Since the revolution, no single group has been dominant,<ref name="Wehrey116"/> although several brigades, or katiba, have been able to exercise considerable strength.
These katiba are “armed fighting groups ranging from 20 to 200 young men, formed along neighborhood, town or regional lines.”<ref name="Wehrey117">{{cite journal|last1=Wehrey|first1=Frederic|title=Libya's Revolution at Two Years: Perils and Achievements|journal=Mediterranean Politics|date=March 2013|volume=18|issue=1|page=117|doi=10.1080/13629395.2013.764655}}</ref> These brigades were central to the military strength of the revolutionary forces.<ref name="Wehrey117"/> After Gaddafi's overthrow, the powerful brigades from Misrata and Zintan raided Tripoli, the Libyan capital, “pillaged automobiles, took over ministries and encamped at key institutions like the airport and oilfields”<ref name="Wehrey117"/> in order to gain political power.
In order to establish democratic legitimacy and sovereignty, the National Transitional Council has had to deal with these brigades, a process which has so far been mostly unsuccessful due to mistrust between the two bodies and the popularly illegitimate but regardless tangible military strength of the brigades.<ref name="Wehrey118">{{cite journal|last1=Wehrey|first1=Frederic|title=Libya's Revolution at Two Years: Perils and Achievements|journal=Mediterranean Politics|date=March 2013|volume=18|issue=1|page=118|doi=10.1080/13629395.2013.764655}}</ref> To firmly establish democratic legitimacy, the National Transitional Council is attempting to draft a new constitution. It has also struggled in this task, for which it is looking back to Libya's first constitution in 1951.<ref name="Wehrey120">{{cite journal|last1=Wehrey|first1=Frederic|title=Libya's Revolution at Two Years: Perils and Achievements|journal=Mediterranean Politics|date=March 2013|volume=18|issue=1|page=120|doi=10.1080/13629395.2013.764655}}</ref>
===Yemen=== [[File:Ali Abdullah Saleh 2004.jpg|thumb|Former Yemeni president Ali Abdullah Saleh operated an extensive, primarily tribal patronage system in Yemen.]] Even before the 2011 revolution, former Yemeni president [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]]’s regime’s legitimacy relied on a patronage network based on the entrenched Yemeni tribal system, effectively tying Saleh’s political legitimacy to the tribes’ much more established and trusted socio-political legitimacy.<ref name="Dingli97">{{cite journal|last1=Dingli|first1=Sophia|title=Is the Failed State Thesis Analytically Useful? The Case of Yemen.|journal=Politics|date=June 2013|volume=33|issue=2|page=97|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9256.2012.01453.x}}</ref><ref name="Longley77">{{cite journal|last1=Longley Alley|first1=April|title=Yemen Changes Everything... and Nothing|journal=Journal of Democracy|date=October 2013|volume=24|issue=4|page=77|doi=10.1353/jod.2013.0070}}</ref> Yemen is historically tribal,<ref name="Yemen">{{cite journal|title=Is Yemen a New Model?|journal=Journal of International Affairs|date=Winter 2013|volume=67|issue=1|page=203}}</ref> with tribes being responsible for defense, keeping the peace, protecting and encouraging trade and markets, and either prohibiting or facilitating travel.<ref name="Dingli97"/> For many Yemenis, tribal systems are “the main or only administrative system they know.”<ref name="Dingli97"/> Tribes function effectively as local governments, introducing generators and water pumps, opening schools, and providing local services.<ref name="Dingli98">{{cite journal|last1=Dingli|first1=Sophia|title=Is the Failed State Thesis Analytically Useful? The Case of Yemen.|journal=Politics|date=June 2013|volume=33|issue=2|page=98|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9256.2012.01453.x}}</ref> Thus, for many “the state is not representative of the Yemeni nation to which they feel they belong.”<ref name="Dingli98"/>
The Yemeni revolution, also part of the Arab Spring, was brought about by the loss of legitimacy by Saleh's regime.<ref name="Change">{{cite journal|title=Change in Yemen|journal=New York Times|date=March 26, 2011|volume=160|issue=55}}</ref> Yemeni youth wanted Saleh's resignation and “a more accountable and democratic system.”<ref name="Change">{{cite journal|title=Change in Yemen|journal=New York Times|date=March 26, 2011|volume=160|issue=55}}</ref> Though reform came slowly due to a lack of support from the international community and the poverty of the protestors<ref name="Eldin194">{{cite journal|last1=Eldin|first1=Kamal|last2=Salih|first2=Osman|title=The Roots and Causes of the 2011 Arab Uprisings|journal=Arab Studies Quarterly|date=Spring 2013|volume=35|issue=2|page=194}}</ref> – Yemen is the Arab world's poorest country<ref name="Dorell">{{cite journal|last1=Dorell|first1=Oren|title=Yemen must address people's problems, analysts say|journal=USA Today|date=February 22, 2012}}</ref> – the anti-Saleh movement gained steam and high-level government officials and tribal leaders joined the opposition against Saleh. The most significant government official to join the revolutionary movement was [[Ali Mohsen al-Ahmar|Major General Ali Mohsin Al-Ahmar]], who ordered his troops to defend antigovernment demonstrators.<ref name="Change">{{cite journal|title=Change in Yemen|journal=New York Times|date=March 26, 2011|volume=160|issue=55}}</ref>
Saleh was deposed and his successor, [[Abd Rabbuh Mansur Hadi|Abdu Rabu Mansour Hadi]], was elected in an uncontested election<ref name="Longley74">{{cite journal|last1=Longley Alley|first1=April|title=Yemen Changes Everything... and Nothing|journal=Journal of Democracy|date=October 2013|volume=24|issue=4|page=74|doi=10.1353/jod.2013.0070}}</ref> to serve as head of the transitional government, which includes the oppositional bloc, the [[Political parties in Yemen|Joint Meeting parties]] (JMP), a five-party alliance including the leading Islamist party [[Islah]] and the [[Yemeni Socialist Party]] (YSP), the Nasirist Popular Unity Party, and two small Islamist [[Zaidiyyah|Zaydi]] parties.<ref name="Longley74"/> The [[National Dialogue Conference]], launched in March 2013, brought together 565 delegates from these parties in order to write a constitution and deal with longstanding challenges to Yemeni governance,<ref name="Longley74"/> such as counterterrorism,<ref name="Yemen">{{cite journal|title=Is Yemen a New Model?|journal=Journal of International Affairs|date=Winter 2013|volume=67|issue=1|page=203}}</ref><ref name="Dorell">{{cite journal|last1=Dorell|first1=Oren|title=Yemen must address people's problems, analysts say|journal=USA Today|date=February 22, 2012}}</ref> development, and the [[South Yemen Movement|Southern Separatist Movement]].<ref name="Sprusansky">{{cite journal|last1=Sprusansky|first1=Dale|title=Yemen's Path Forward|journal=Washington Report on Middle East Affairs|date=February 2013|volume=32|issue=1}}</ref>
Although Yemen was the only country from the 2011 Arab Spring to emerge with a negotiated settlement with the current regime and a transition plan for a national dialogue,<ref name="Longley74"/> by 2013 there was “no significant redistribution of resources or hard power outside the traditional elite.”<ref name="Longley74"/> The vestiges of Saleh's regime<ref name="Dingli99">{{cite journal|last1=Dingli|first1=Sophia|title=Is the Failed State Thesis Analytically Useful? The Case of Yemen.|journal=Politics|date=June 2013|volume=33|issue=2|page=99|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9256.2012.01453.x}}</ref><ref name="Longley75">{{cite journal|last1=Longley Alley|first1=April|title=Yemen Changes Everything... and Nothing|journal=Journal of Democracy|date=October 2013|volume=24|issue=4|page=75|doi=10.1353/jod.2013.0070}}</ref> and a lack of support from southern tribes<ref name="Longley75"/><ref name="Longley83">{{cite journal|last1=Longley Alley|first1=April|title=Yemen Changes Everything... and Nothing|journal=Journal of Democracy|date=October 2013|volume=24|issue=4|page=83|doi=10.1353/jod.2013.0070}}</ref><ref name="Proper">{{cite journal|title=No proper end|journal=The Economist|date=January 25, 2014|volume=410|issue=8871}}</ref> plagued the National Dialogue Conference, which consequently finished four months later than expected, in January 2014.<ref name="Proper">{{cite journal|title=No proper end|journal=The Economist|date=January 25, 2014|volume=410|issue=8871}}</ref> Further elections were indefinitely postponed, leading to speculation that Hadi and members of the parliament will keep their positions indefinitely.<ref name="Proper">{{cite journal|title=No proper end|journal=The Economist|date=January 25, 2014|volume=410|issue=8871}}</ref> Due to these complications, there is currently no legitimate unifying political body in Yemen.
==International crises of legitimacy== The implications of an international crisis of legitimacy usually reach further than domestic crises, given that the actors have power over several different countries. International crises can threaten the stability between countries, increasing the probability for conflict.
===The European Union=== The [[European Union]] (E.U.) is a governing body over 28 European countries. The E.U. does not have complete legitimacy over the citizens of the 28 countries given that it only governs in the realm of politics and economics. Additionally, the E.U. does not operate under [[majority rule]] meaning any one country can veto laws.<ref name="Vobruba">{{cite journal|last1=Vobruba|first1=Georg|title=The Limits for Legitimation. Preconditions for Conflict Resolution by Majority Rule in the European Union|journal=Czech Sociological Review|date=December 2006|volume=42|issue=6|pages=1137–1150}}</ref> The E.U. suffered a legitimation crisis when it attempted to pass a constitution which failed in the [[French European Constitution referendum, 2005]].<ref name="Brunkhorst">{{cite journal|last1=Brunkhorst|first1=Hauke|title=The Legitimation Crisis of the European Union|journal=Constellations|date=June 2006|volume=13|issue=2|pages=165–180|doi=10.1111/j.1351-0487.2006.00448.x}}</ref><ref name="Vaara">{{cite journal|last1=Vaara|first1=E.|title=Struggles over legitimacy in the Eurozone crisis: Discursive legitimation strategies and their ideological underpinnings|journal=Discourse & Society|date=6 July 2014|volume=25|issue=4|pages=500–518|doi=10.1177/0957926514536962}}</ref>
===The United States=== During the [[Cold war era|Cold War era]], most European Countries respected the authority of the United States as an international leader.<ref name="Kagan">{{cite journal|last1=Kagan|first1=Robert|title=America's Crisis of Legitimacy|journal=Foreign Affairs|date=2004|volume=83|pages=65–87|doi=10.2307/20033903}}</ref> Europeans accepted the United States as the primary defender against the [[Soviet Union]]. After the Soviet Union fell, however, some scholars believe the United States was no longer needed by the Europeans for that purpose and therefore lost international legitimacy.<ref name=Kagan />
==In the United States== [[File:1963 march on washington.jpg|thumb|left|Civil Rights March on Washington, D.C. in August, 1963.]]
===1950s through 1980s=== {{multiple image | footer = Al Gore and George Bush, the Democratic and Republican candidates for the 2000 presidential election. | align = right
| image1 = Al Gore.jpg | alt1 = Al Gore | width1 = 130
| image2 = GeorgeWBush.jpg | alt2 = George W. Bush | width2 = 155 }}
In this time period, it was accepted by many political theorists that the United States was undergoing a crisis of legitimacy.<ref name="Friedrichs2">{{cite journal|last1=Friedrichs|first1=David O.|title=The Legitimacy Crisis in the United States: A Conceptual Analysis|journal=Social Problems|date=June 1980|volume=27|issue=5|pages=540–555|doi=10.2307/800195|jstor=800195}}</ref> Minorities in the United States began to question the legitimacy of the government because they felt they were being denied rights.<ref name="Kateb">{{cite journal|last1=Kateb|first1=George|title=On the "Legitimation Crisis"|journal=Social Research|date=Winter 1979|volume=46|issue=4|pages=695–727|jstor=40970809}}</ref> The mindset was transferred into movements beginning in the [[Civil Rights Movement]], which primarily involved African Americans and college students but eventually spread to a larger portion of the population.<ref name="Friedrichs2"/> The United States government's reaction to the legitimation crisis of the late twentieth century shows that in a consolidated democracy, undergoing a legitimation crisis can strengthen legitimacy. In this case, the system adapted to the wants of the citizens and the United States re-established legitimacy.<ref name="Friedrichs2"/> In the mid 1960s, the legitimacy of the United States government was challenged when citizens began to question the [[legality of the Vietnam War]].<ref name="Hendrickson">{{cite journal|last1=Hendrickson|first1=David|title=The Sources of American Legitimacy|journal=Foreign Affairs|date=November 2004|url=http://www.cfr.org/world/sources-american-legitimacy/p7473}}</ref><ref name="Summers">{{cite book|last1=Summers|first1=Harry|title=On Strategy: A Critical Analysis of the Vietnam War|date=1995|publisher=Presidio Press|page=34}}</ref>
===2000: Bush v. Gore reelection===
In the United States 2000 presidential election, [[United States presidential election, 2000]], Bush lost the popular vote but still won the electoral vote. Many United States citizens did not believe this was right. The legitimacy of the United States came into question after the Supreme Court Decision, [[Bush v. Gore]].<ref name="Casebeer">{{cite journal|last1=Casebeer|first1=Kenneth|title=A cautionary tale: Globalisation and legitimation crisis in the rule of law in the United States|journal=International Journal of the Legal Profession|date=March 2001|volume=8|issue=1|pages=57–68|doi=10.1080/09695950120103181|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=aph&AN=5655234&site=ehost-live&scope=site}}</ref> While some believe the legitimacy of the presidency came into question,<ref name="Friedrichs2"/> others believe the legitimacy of the court was jeopardized after the decision was released<ref name="Yates">{{cite journal|last1=Yates|first1=Jeffrey|last2=Whitford|first2=Andrew|title=The Presidency and the Supreme Court After Bush v. Gore|journal=Stanford Law & Policy Review|date=2002|volume=13|issue=1|pages=101–118}}</ref><ref name="Ackerman">{{cite book|last1=Ackerman|first1=Bruce|title=Bush v. Gore: The Question of Legitimacy|date=October 2002|publisher=Yale University Press|pages=39–49}}</ref> In the aftermath of the decision, six hundred and seventy five law professors argued against the decision in ''The New York Times.''<ref name="Friedrichs2"/>
==Resolution== When an actor loses [[Legitimacy (political)|legitimacy]], the public no longer trusts the actor to maintain a [[social contract]]. Without the social contract, the natural rights of the public, such as life, liberty, and property,<ref name="Powell">{{cite web|last1=Powell|first1=Jim|title=John Locke: Natural Rights to Life, Liberty, and Property|url=http://fee.org/the_freeman/detail/john-locke-natural-rights-to-life-liberty-and-property|website=The Freeman}}</ref> are in jeopardy.<ref name="Fabienne2">{{cite web|last1=Peter|first1=Fabienne|last2=Zalta|first2=Edward|title=Political Legitimacy|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/legitimacy/#FunPolLeg|website=Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|publisher=The Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University|accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref> Therefore, it is usually in the interest of both the public and the actor to end the legitimation crisis.There are several ways in which to end a legitimation crisis, but there is currently no unified theory as for the best method. Although the actor could be replaced, as seen in many of the examples above and effectively ending the legitimation crisis, this section will focus on the [[conflict resolution]] of the crisis. In this situation, the actor that was seeking legitimacy before the crisis regains legitimacy.
An actor can regain legitimacy in two ways: # Re-establish the base: realigning the political actions to the widely accepted social values and norms. In 1956 in Montgomery, Alabama, the more than year-long [[Montgomery Bus Boycott]] eventually led to repeal of the local ordinance for bus segregation. In this case, by realigning the laws to fit with public opinion, the government was able to regain legitimacy. # Coerce legitimacy: drawing on capital goods to create a "material source of power."<ref name="Reus-Smit">{{cite journal|last1=Reus-Smit|first1=Christian|title=International Crises of Legitimacy|journal=International Politics|date=2007|volume=44|pages=157–174|url=http://www.palgrave-journals.com/ip/journal/v44/n2/full/8800182a.html|accessdate=8 November 2014|doi=10.1057/palgrave.ip.8800182}}</ref> In the [[Rwandan Genocide]] in 1994, the loss of government legitimacy led to an outbreak in genocide. One of the political factions, the Hutu, killed thousands of members of the Tutsi party. The RPF had to rely on the capital goods of the international community, in the form of weapons and money, and thus were able to regain control and legitimacy in Rwanda.

''[[The Republic (Plato)|The Republic]]'' |- | ca. 335-323 B.C. | Aristotle. ''[[Politics (Aristotle)|Politics]]'' Aristotle. ''[[Nicomachean Ethics]]'' |- | 1517 | Machiavelli, N. ''[[The Social Construction of Reality]]'' |- | 1968 | Scott, M. B., & Lyman, S. M. "Accounts" Stinchcombe, A. ''Constructing Social Theories'' |- | 1972 | Berger, J., Zelditch, M., Cohen, B.
