revision.text:
{{Infobox book | italic title = <!--(see above)--> | name = Tomorrowland: Our Journey from Science Fiction to Science Fact | image = Tomorrowland Cover.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Cover for ''Tomorrowland'' | author = [[Steven Kotler]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | subject = [[popular science]], [[emerging technologies]] | genre = [[Non-fiction]] | set_in = | publisher = [[Amazon Publishing]] ([[Little A]] and [[Amazon Publishing|New Harvest]]) | publisher2 = | pub_date = May 12, 2015 | media_type = | pages = 288 | awards = | isbn = 978-0-544-45621-1 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''Tomorrowland: Our Journey from Science Fiction to Science Fact''''' is a 2015 [[non-fiction]] book by [[science journalist]] [[Steven Kotler]] and published by [[Amazon Publishing]].
==Content== The book is composed of a series of essay articles that were published by Kotler in various online news publications, including ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The Atlantic]]'', and ''[[Discover (magazine)|Discover]]''. There are sixteen chapters made up of the same number of articles, each dealing with a different topic of technological innovation in a variety of fields.<ref>{{cite news |last=Constant |first=Paul |date=May 23, 2015 |title=‘Tomorrowland’ (The Book) And the Heartbreak of Prediction |url=http://recode.net/2015/05/23/tomorrowland-the-book-and-the-heartbreak-of-prediction/ |newspaper=[[Re/code]] |access-date=April 12, 2016}}</ref>
==Critical reception== ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'' praised Kotler for not just presenting the technological innovations themselves, but also focusing on the "obsessive people behind the science" and how his insight into their work encompasses a "range from humane and gripping stories of redemption to indifferent research scientists unsure if their developments will even make the world a better place".<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Kirkus Review: Tomorrowland |url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/steven-kotler/tomorrowland/ |newspaper=[[Kirkus Reviews]] |date=March 5, 2015 |access-date=April 12, 2016}}</ref> ''[[Library Journal]]'' reviewer Talea Anderson also noted the introduction of each essay and discussed technology focusing on "presenting the array of often quirky inventors and early adopters who have engaged with it" and ultimately recommended the book for readers of [[popular science]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Anderson |first=Talea |date=April 15, 2015 |title=Review: Tomorrowland: Our Journey from Science Fiction to Science Fact |url=http://web.a.ebscohost.com/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?sid=03e0ff25-e224-4864-8732-6f02b39e53a6%40sessionmgr4002&vid=1&hid=4106 |journal=[[Library Journal]] |publisher=[[Media Source]] |volume=140 |issue=7 |pages=113-114 |issn=0363-0277 |access-date=April 12, 2016}} {{subscription required}}</ref> In a separate review in ''Library Journal'' of the audiobook, reviewer Lisa Youngblood recommended the book and its look at not only the technology, but also the "social and moral questions that arise" from the potential ramifications of the [[emerging technologies]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Youngblood |first=Lisa |date=August 1, 2015 |title=Media Review: Tomorrowland: Our Journey from Science Fiction to Science Fact |url=http://web.a.ebscohost.com/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?sid=94ea4742-acd5-49d4-a5be-72e7854ad6a3%40sessionmgr4004&vid=1&hid=4106 |journal=[[Library Journal]] |publisher=[[Media Source]] |volume=140 |issue=13 |pages=49 |issn=0363-0277 |access-date=April 12, 2016}} {{subscription required}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal| Books | Literature}} * [[Futurology]] * ''[[Abundance: The Future Is Better Than You Think]]'' * ''[[Bold: How to Go Big, Create Wealth, and Impact the World]]''
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.stevenkotler.com/tomorrowland/ Official website]
[[Category:2015 American novels]] [[Category:Technology books]] [[Category:Environmental non-fiction books]] [[Category:Futurology books]] [[Category:American non-fiction books]]

revision.comment: fix cite for bar "|.." in title
revision.text:
[[file:Wendy Sadler FameLab International 2014 (cropped).jpg|thumb|in 2014]] '''Wendy Sadler''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|MBE}} is a British [[science communication|science communicator]] and lecturer at [[Cardiff University]]. She is the founding director of Science Made Simple<ref>[http://www.sciencemadesimple.co.uk/ Science Made Simple]</ref> which focuses on engaging audiences with the physical sciences. Her areas of interest include inspiring the next generation of scientists, engineers and communicators; [[Women in STEM fields|women in STEM]]; and making [[Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|STEM]] subjects accessible to diverse audiences.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.sciencemadesimple.co.uk/about/staff/wendy-sadler|title=Wendy Sadler -|work=science made simple|access-date=2018-10-08|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Education and career == Sadler was born in 1972 and grew up in Wolverhampton, England.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.compassmr.co.uk/news/science-advocate-receives-mbe-queens-birthday-honours/|title=Science advocate receives MBE in Queen's birthday honours - Compass Media Relations|date=2017-06-19|work=Compass Media Relations|access-date=2017-12-28|language=en-US}}</ref> After graduating Cardiff University with a BSc in Physics and Music in 1994, Sadler considered a career as an acoustic engineer before becoming a manager at [[Techniquest]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/rugby-pundit-jonathan-davies-adds-1908309|title=Rugby pundit Jonathan Davies adds to his honours|last=Turner|first=Robin|date=2010-07-15|work=walesonline|access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://speakingofscience.juliegould.net/science-communication/speaking-to-wendy-sadler/|title=Speaking to...Wendy Sadler - Speaking of Science {{!}} Science Communication|date=2012-11-19|work=Speaking of Science|access-date=2017-12-28|language=en-US}}</ref> She has since completed an MSc in Science Communication at the Open University.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Wendy-Sadler/e/B001K8QG3G|title=Amazon.co.uk: Wendy Sadler: Books, Biography, Blogs, Audiobooks, Kindle|website=www.amazon.co.uk|access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref> Her dissertation assessed the long-term impact of science demonstration shows.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sciencemadesimple.co.uk/about/research_evaluation|title=Research and Evaluation -|work=science made simple|access-date=2017-12-28|language=en-US}}</ref> She created the non-verbal theatre show called The Experimentrics, which mixed physical theatre and live science demonstrations to create "a world of wordless mystery and fun".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.experimentrics.co.uk/about/|title=About - The Experimentrics|work=The Experimentrics|access-date=2017-12-28|language=en-US}}</ref> Sadler is a LAMDA accredited public speaker and fellow of the Royal Society of the Arts. She regularly appears on television and radio discussing the importance of STEM education.<ref>{{Citation|last=ScienceMadeSimpleUK|title=Wendy Sadler on Why We Need Science In Schools - The Wales Report, BBC|date=2013-07-03|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=duyrZqBsCQM&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2017-12-28}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Wendy Sadler|title=Wendy on Alan Titchmarsh show 26th Oct|date=2012-04-07|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dDdZ_yukdKU&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2017-12-28}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Ignite Cardiff|title=Science Vs Ghosts (Ignite Cardiff 14 - Episode 2 - Wendy Sadler)|date=2013-12-19|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q_EaHC2O0pw&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2017-12-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/science/leadingedge_20050310.shtml|title=BBC - Radio 4 - Leading Edge 10/03/2005|last=BBC|website=www.bbc.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref> Sadler is a Lecturer and Schools' Liaison Officer at Cardiff University.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cardiff.ac.uk/people/view/913831-sadler-wendy|title=Wendy Sadler|work=People|access-date=2017-12-28|language=en}}</ref> She is concerned about the state of science education in Wales.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://soapboxscience.org/is-wales-in-a-science-education-crisis/|title=Is Wales in a science-education crisis? - SoapboxScience|date=2015-04-28|work=SoapboxScience|access-date=2017-12-28|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Public engagement == Sadler is a physics communicator who has published 19 books for children.<ref name=":0" /> She has contributed to ITV Wales, BBC Radio and the Edinburgh Fringe Festival.<ref name=":0" /> In 2010 Sadler gave a TEDxCardiff talk entitled "Music and the Machine".<ref>{{Citation|last=TEDx Talks|title=TEDxCardiff - Wendy Sadler - Music and the Machine|date=2010-06-13|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d15EdTBjv4k&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2017-12-28}}</ref>
== Science Made Simple == Sadler set up Science Made Simple (SMS) in 2002 with the mission to inspire the next generation of scientists and engineers.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://leadingwalesawards.co.uk/social-enterprse-2015/|title=Social Enterprise 2015|website= Leading Wales Awards 2017|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref> At the time, Sadler was the IOP Schools Lecturer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iop.org/news/17/june/page_69622.html|title=Five IOP members receive Queen's Birthday Honours|last=Physics|first=Institute of|website=www.iop.org|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref> SMS develop and present interactive performances that travel to schools and festivals across the world, reaching 28 countries to date.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cardiffmet.ac.uk/news/Pages/20Twenty-Graduate-named-Winner-at-Leading-Wales-Awards-2015.aspx|title=20Twenty Graduate named Winner at Leading Wales Awards 2015|website=[[Cardiff Metropolitan University]]|language=en|access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref> They have produced shows, contributed to science television, radio programmes, and children's books, trained scientists and acted as consultants on UK research councils.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.iop.org/interactions/archive/INTApr07totalWeb.pdf|title=Newsmakers|last=|first=|date=|work=Interactions: The Newspaper of The Physics Community|access-date=2017-12-28|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> In 2013, she received national media coverage for their tour of UK primary schools following a sell-out run at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-25085193|title=Silent science show targets children|date=2013-11-25|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-12-28|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cardiff.ac.uk/news/view/34706-inspiring-young-scientists|title=Inspiring young scientists|work=News|access-date=2017-12-28|language=en}}</ref> SMS has reached more than 750,000 people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.astro.cf.ac.uk/newsandevents/?page=news_detail&news=0236|title=News|website=www.astro.cf.ac.uk|access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref> SMS is part of a multimillion-pound EU project investigating the use of performance as a tool to engage young people with science and society issues.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sciencemadesimple.co.uk/training/perform-project|title=The EU funded PERFORM Project -|work=science made simple|access-date=2017-12-28|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Work with the [[Welsh Government]] == Sadler Chaired and co-authored the Task and Finish report on STEM engagement in Wales for the National Science Academy<ref>{{Cite web |url= https://gov.wales/topics/science-and-technology/science/national-science-academy/?lang=en |title=Welsh Government {{!}} National Science Academy |website= gov.wales |language=EN |access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> and was involved in the writing of the Talented Women for a Successful Wales<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gov.wales/docs/det/report/160308-women-in-science-en.pdf|title=Talented Women for a Successful Wales|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> report.<ref name=":2" />
